<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">
            <choice>
              <sic>1o</sic>
              <corr>10</corr>
            </choice>
          </l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">The writer then came to birth with difficulty in England--</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">the writer who is distinct from the minstrel, whose words</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">are printed. For when familiar 
            <choice>
              <sic>lettees</sic>
              <corr>letters</corr>
            </choice> are written in</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">Biblical prose there must be axmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmxm</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">a barrier between what is sayable and what unsayable.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">a limit thus to what he can put into words <add hand="ms" place="above">writing</add>.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">He is in being <add hand="ms" place="inline">,</add> at the beginning of the sixteenth century;</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">for the 
            <choice>
              <sic>priting</sic>
              <corr>printing</corr>
            </choice> press has given him a name; but he is still</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">unspecialised, undifferentiated. The artist --the person</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">who stands 
            <choice>
              <sic>otside</sic>
              <corr>outside</corr>
            </choice> amxmxmxmxmxmxmxmx, by some impulse</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">desiring to observe <add hand="ms" place="above">to</add> state <add hand="ms" place="above">rather than to take part</add> -- is not wholly writer,</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">wholly musician, or wholly painter. It seems possible</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">that the great English art may not be the art of words.</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">His eye like a painters, is alive to the 
            <choice>
              <sic>clour</sic>
              <corr>colour</corr>
            </choice> of</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">clothing, of country, of beats and birds; his ear, like</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">a musicians, is stimulated by the sound of words spoken aloud</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><del hand="ms">His book</del> <add hand="typewriter" place="above">What he wrote</add> was read out<del hand="ms">aloud</del> <add hand="ms" place="above">in company</add>. <quote source="#" rend="inline">"I spent most of my time"</quote></l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">wrote <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-aclif" key="Clifford, Ann">Lady Ann Clifford</rs> <quote source="#" rend="inline">in playing <del hand="ms">Glocko</del> at Glecko,</quote></l>

<quote xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" source="#" rend="inline">
            <l>and hearing <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-mnev" key="Neville, Moll">Moll Neville</rs> read <rs type="literary-work" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#lit-arca" key="Countess of Pembroke's Arcadia">the Arcadia."</rs>.. <rs type="person" ref="psn-unkn">Rivers</rs> used</l>
            <l>to read to me on <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-mmon" key="Montaigne, Michel de">Montaigne</rs> <rs type="literary-work" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#lit-essa" key="Essais (Michel de Montaigne)"/> and Moll Neville in the</l>
          </quote>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><quote source="#" rend="inline"><rs type="lit" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#lit-faer" key="Faerie Queene, The">Faery Queen"</rs></quote> (1617-1619) Every word had its 
            <choice>
              <sic>sharpnes</sic>
              <corr>sharpness</corr>
            </choice> <add hand="ms" place="above">weight</add></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">its weight <add hand="ms" place="above">& edge</add> given to it by the speaking voice. And then the</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">lute and the virginals gave lilt, rhythm melody to the</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">written words. When the fire of London was burning <add hand="typewriter" place="above">and the citizens loading their goods 
            <choice>
              <sic>intob</sic>
              <corr>into boats</corr>
            </choice></add></l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-spep" key="Pepys, Samuel">Pepys</rs> noted that <quote source="#">"Hardly one lighter or 
            <choice>
              <sic>baot</sic>
              <corr>boat</corr>
            </choice> in three</quote></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><quote source="#" rend="inline">that had the goods of of a house in it, but there was a</quote></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><quote source="#" rend="inline">pair of virginals in it."</quote> The writers mind was full</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">of 
            <choice>
              <sic>undiffrentiated</sic>
              <corr>undifferentiated</corr>
            </choice> words; old words, new words; French and</l>
